question: What are the materials of the Wet Gas Cooler/Chiller made of?
correct_answer: Vertically mounted with Titanium tube sheets and fiberglass heads.
choices: What conditions could we get dry Cl2 gas to the chillers and what to do to address it  Titanium and dry chlorine can cause a chlorine/steel fire. If a circuit is down dry chlorine could get back through the system. To address it we isolate valves on the Drying Towers and turn on the Brinks Wash/ or Hot Condensate on top of the W/G Chiller to wet the tubes.
None. Verify cooling tower water flow.

It can result in high exit temperature in the cl2 gas exiting the chiller. This can cause High acid usage in the Drying Towers and can result in elevated moisture moisture exiting the Drying Towers. Moisture will increase the D/T operating temperature. Should increase Strong Acid makeup to the D/T to compensate for moisture.
Vertically mounted with Titanium tube sheets and fiberglass heads.

question: What is the purpose/ why do we dry chlorine?
correct_answer: We dry chlorine so that it can be handled in the carbon steel piping.
choices: The temperature exiting the drying towers, moisture monitors at the Elliotts, good acid strength and circulation in drying towers. Explain how to take a section out of service. The bottom section must be above 85% to ensure adequate drying. Shut off the pump of the section that is being taken out of service (top/middle) and swap strong acid makeup.
After, it could get dry chlorine wet and cause corrosion in equipment and piping.

Too low will cause elevated moisture exiting the Drying Towers with subsequent corrosion of carbon steel piping and equipment downstream. Too high will cause additional acid consumption (cost effective) and could cause damage to the Spent Acid storage tanks.
We dry chlorine so that it can be handled in the carbon steel piping.
